content.description:
A fun route with the crux right at the top at the big undercling. Beware of the polished holds.

The 4th route from the left. Climbs the line of bolts to the most obvious large undercling (yellowish). Anchor is right above the undercling and hidden from the ground.
quickdraws, chain anchor.

A short but fun route. Start in the middle left of the slabby ledge and go through the bulge on good holds up to the overhang where you'll find an old aluminum bolt hanger. Pull through the roof to the chains.



Far right hand side of first rock and up the hill to a dirt ledge.

3 bolts with the final one being an old aluminum hanger.

Climb out of the yellow hole using almost entirely very technical feet. Good holds lead to a high second crux through a crumbly section of rock to the shared anchor with Potentilla Pillar.

Furthest left line at First Rock, hike up a small trail to the ledge where the climb starts.
8 bolts to a bolted anchor.

A tough route for 5.9 due to the polished nature of some of the holds, especially the bulge 2/3rd of the way of the route. Trust your hands more than your feet on this one.

Climbs the obvious small left facing corner/crack. Starts just right of the tree almost touching the wall. The 9th route from the left of the wall.
quickdraws, chain anchor with fixed sport locker.

Very slabby, limited hand holds but good feet.

This climb is located towards the right side of First Rock. Follow the path where it goes up to the right, and you'll see a gully on your left. This route starts with some easy scrambling through this gully to the first bolt, before tending to the right on slab.


Bolted

This route is more of an approach route for Brownout (5.10c) and Potentilla Pillar (5.8), but has it's own 2 bolt anchor atop the ledge after 3 bolts. Best combined as one pitch with either of the two above mentioned routes.

Farthest left rought on First Rock (Left). Starts just left of the tree.
Quickdraws, 3 bolts & a 2 bolt anchor

Start a couple meters left of the short left facing corner, pull big jugs and relatively easy moves up to the 4th bolt and then enjoy figuring out a tricky crux.

2 meters left of the small left facing corner, right of Feel On Baby.
4 bolts to bolted anchor.

The crux is once again near the top where the holds get very thin, slopey, and polished. There is a bit of distance between the second and third bolt. A fun outing.

The 5th route from the left. The line of bolts next to Back to Zero, which is identified by the large yellowish undercling near its finish.
quickdraws, chain anchor

A fun route that starts just right of Feel On and, although graded the same (5.10b), felt definitely harder to me.

Starts just right of Feel On. The 6th route from the left.
Quickdraws, chain anchor

Climb up the slab right of the bulge to a high first bolt. Clip a second bolt and traverse left on easy slab under the roof with a small tree growing out of the ledge above you. Clip an old aluminum hanger and make easy but committing moves over the roof to the anchor. 

Between the ratty old bolt and significant distance between bolts this might be a heady lead for a 5.9 climber.



Right of the bulge in the area far right of first rock and up the hill.

3 bolts.

Gain an easy high first bolt, pull a couple tough moves and then continue through mostly easy climbing with one more thought provoking move at the small roof.

Line right of Potentilla Pillar.
10 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Continues above the top of Trio and trends to the right to an anchor over a roof


Bolted

I see 5.8 in the Dr. Topo guide, but the moves getting past the 2nd bolt felt 5.10. The climb is two parts and the second section after the intermediate ledge is very steep, but has better holds than the lower section. A fun long climb.

3rd route from the left, just right of the tree that almost touches the rock face. The top half may be a different route, but well worth doing both as one 28m pitch.
Quickdraws, chain anchor.

A fantastic route with a very ugly looking vegetated start that doesn't actually diminish any of the climbing.

Climb through 3 bolts of vegetated rock before trending left of the flake into nice stances with thoughtful movement and good feet. Fantastic up high!



Second bolted line from the left in the main area before you go up the hill. Vegetated first couple bolts.

9 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Start up mossy but easy rock working your way to underneath the left trending crack. Pull up and over it (crux) to easier climbing above. The anchor is a couple meters left and up from the final bolt.

The bolted line that starts under the large left facing crack and goes straight up over it.
10 bolts to a bolted anchor.

The extension to Duet, this route takes the right hand variation after clipping the anchors. Fun climbing and there is a hidden bolt near the top where it looks like the bolts run out. Just keep climbing up and it will magically appear

Starts atop the ledge above Duet. Most will link Duet and Potentilla Pillar as one pitch.
quickdraws, chain anchor.

Same start as Cavebird but then head right at the first bolt and climb right of the flake through some thin moves and eventually a ledge with the anchors. Just right of the super popular flake corner route Cavebird. 4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Start with a very low bolt you can clip from the ground, moving up onto a insecure feeling ledge and trending left (straight up is the 10c variation) on what feels like blank rock at times. Trust your feet. 

First bolt is about 8 feet off the ground, right in front of a dead Aspen tree.
7 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Easy climbing leads to hard-ish crimp-pulling until you reach the "thank god pocket". Feels tough for the grade!



Middle-right on the wall, just left of the obvious left-facing corner / crack through which Cavebird (5.9) climbs. 

Bolts + chains.

Clip an easy bolt on the side of the bulge, pull left through moves that are easier than they look up to the crux at the 3rd bolt. Crank through some crimps and body tension moves up onto the ledge for the finish.

First line just right of the light grey/blue streak in the middle of the wall.
4 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Quite polished.

Bolted.

Start below the tallest tree on the ledge about 30 feet up. Clip a high bolt followed by a couple bouldery and insecure moves to gain an awesome hold after the second bolt and top out to anchors between the trees.

Below the tallest tree on the ledge about 30 feet up, left of the large left facing crack. 
3 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Sun exposure: Sunny morning till early afternoon 
 Crowds: can be heavy on the weekend with climbers and tourists 
 Rock type/quality: Excellent quality grey limestone, can be slick 
  
 First Rock is, as it's name implies, the first climbing rock as one heads up the Heart Creek Interpretive Trail. Home to ~28 climbs in the 5.5 - 5.11b range.
